results.notes:
In a general area with ponderosa pine, fir, and mountain harwoods.
Found in small groups of 2 to 4. A group in a hole of the stump, another outside close to the ground in front of the stump. This was probably a ponderosa pine stump, and this contradicts Volk’s description (?).
Caps 2 to 5 cms., orange/brown to dark brown, not scaly, splitting, (Cold, late on the season). Gills pinkish, close to subdistant, broad, adnate to subdecurrent, with spots. Stipe dark brown, solid, with traces of a veil. Veil pinkish, cottony, ragged, apparently evanescent.
Spore print snow white.
Basidia (30-40) x (6-9) clavate; with a refractory content, almost siderophylous, some basidia is empty, totally transparent and if loose appear like cystidia. Cystidia also as thin filaments more slender than the basidia.
Spores smooth, elliptical or oval, some narrowing towards the apiculus (7.0-8.2) x (5.0-5.5), some thick walled, character to which I am giving extra value for this identification.

results.notes: Morphology: parabolic to obtusely-conical, pale brownish (sometimes medium- or somewhat olivaceous- brown) cap with brighter nearly or semi- umbonate translucent tip of a separable layer, straited margins (occasionally incurved) with thin flesh, frequently chipped or split and appearing ragged; gills pale (whitish) pinkish-brown to dark brown; whitish often splintered stem stains grayish-brown. Spore print: benzo brown. Spores: {Nov. 1st} elongated-broadly ellipsoid (occasionally amygdaliform), brownish [N=45] measure (8.5)9.1 – 11.2(12.1) × (4.6)5.1 – 6.3(6.7) µm; Me = 10.1 × 5.7 µm; Qe = 1.8. Growth pattern: scattered. Measurements: {Nov. 1st} [n=3] cap 10.9-21.5 across by 8.15-12.5 mm high; stem 1.2-1.85 (widest right at intersection with cap, nearly equal) thick by 37.3-78.2 mm tall. {Nov. 14th} [n=1] cap 11.0 across, 7.9 mm high; stem 1.1 thick by 39.4 mm tall. {Nov. 27th} [n=1] cap 12.34 across by 6.92 mm high; stem 1.30 thick by 52.5 mm tall. Habitat: partly shaded woodland trailside, growing around an elm with dense surrounding cover from neighboring young trees and fallen woody debris, from moist soil rich in twigs, leaf and bark flakes, lightly admixed with woodchips.

results.notes: Zone 9a on the Gulf Coast growing in groundcover that took over lawn grass in pure quartz sand soil. The stem is very delicate. It appears to have fruited from a small myceliated twig under the surface of the soil. The gills are grey with splotches of dark spores. I’m taking a spore print and will update the observation later with the result.
results.location_name: Panama City Beach, Florida, USA

results.notes:
Zone 9a on the Gulf Coast growing at the base of Heterotheca subaxillaris, Camphor weed, which is where I almost always find these little mushrooms. They are in groundcover that took over lawn grass in pure quartz sand soil. The specimens in this group range from 1.5-2cm across the top of the cap. I have also included a photo of the Camphorweed around which they like to grow.

There is something interesting pinning right next to it in the third photo. Could that be a G. Luteofolius pinning next to these? I will add an observation for that mushroom once it makes more progress.

results.notes:
Fruiting beneath Sitka Spruce and Western Hemlock. 
Cap: pink, darker pink at central disc. 
Gills: purple/black from spore drop at maturity.  Pinkish when young.
Stem: swollen at base(especially younger specimens). Juvenile/young fruits with distinctly pointed cap. 
Odor: fruity with young specimens in this collection. Like maraschino Cherry or banana.
Harvested 5 specimens.  Many attached to mass of rooting tissue(bonded to needle litter and woody debris).
Spore printed a single younger cap directly on glass slide for microscopy. 
Spore Print: purple/black-purple brown(see images). 
Spores: ellipsoid, smooth with Germ Pore. See images of microscopy dry(1st).  See images.
Mounted a section in KOH. 
Spores yellow in KOH.(see images).
 Dehydrated all specimens and bagged for herbarium collection/genetic record.

results.notes: Morphology: broadly-umbonate, obtusely-conic (rather campanulate) or convex cap that is nearly symmetrical, reddish-brown fading to beige with dark umber band and orange-brown umbo, margin undulating, often irregularly edged and not striated; brownish-umber gills close to crowded; somewhat lustrous white stem is stiff, staining bright yellow, easily splits. Growth pattern: gregarious. Measurements: [n=3] cap 26.8-37.2 across by 6.1-18.9 mm high, stem 3.1-4.0 thick (widening towards top and base) by 42.3 [91.2 with root] to 61.7 [no root] mm tall. Habitat: fairly well shaded woodland from moist woodchips admixed with decaying young roots.

results.notes:
Found growing from underneath disrurbed soil (propably dung was present although there was no foul smell), surrounded by grass, holm oak trees and other uknown bushes, the habitat was right next to a pinus forest.
Gills color: white or light yellow
Gill attachement: free (not sure)
Gill spacing: sub distant
Annulus: none
Stem shape: flexuose suurounded by very large fibers running all along the stem, the color of the stem matches that of the cap, at first we thought it was a tree branch underneath the soil, till we saw the gills..
Stem length: 80 mm
Stem radius: 6 mm
Cap shape: obtusely conic, it seems to be missing a chunck, propably hit by a boar (fresh wounds and boar marks).
Cap radius: 20 to 24 in millimeters
Partial veil: none
Whitish fringe along the edges: not sure
Bruising reaction color: none, although 60% of the stem (bottom, up) turned into blakish color after 3 hours from picking (see photo at desk).
Gelatinous pellicle: not present
The specimen was handled in a wax paper bag, after examination the cap was cut for spore printing, the cap was facing down a blank white paper covered with glass, it was left to print for 24 hours but no spores were found..

results.notes: Morphology: acutely- to obtusely-conic deep reddish-brown, umber-brown to grayish-beige cap without striated margins; stem whitish staining yellowish-gray, usually flexuose, quite flexible, snaps instead of splits. Spore print: blackish. Spores: ellipsoid, brownish [N=30] measure (10.6)12.3 – 14.3(15.4) × (5.7)6.7 – 7.6(8.6) µm; Me = 13.2 × 7.2 µm; Qe = 1.8. Growth pattern: scattered-gregarious, occasional to rather frequent. Measurements: [n=4] cap 12.9-16.3 across, 7.6-10.7 mm high, stem 1.2-1.9 thick by 47.1-60.6 mm tall. Habitat: well shaded woodlot trailside (often scattered beneath a layer of leaves) from soil rich in woody debris including decayed woodchips.

results.notes:
On mossy ground along the border between a stand of Scots pine and a mowed open area.
Spores were collected from two different fruit bodies; two of the smaller ones.
fb1: spores 7.5-9.5 × 4.5-5.5 (nearly) smooth; no distinct warts (as seen in KOH at 400x).
fb2: spores 9-11 × 5-7 appearing punctate with very small warts (as seen in KOH at 400x).
Spore morphology suggests there are two distinct species seen here.

Hopefully, there will be more of these to examine in the near future; the location typically produces several species of Cort throughout the month of November. The fbs seen in this observation were growing scattered in two different patches (mossy patches maybe 25 feet apart).

results.notes: Found on the wet trunk on an Arbutus menziesii (Pacific madrone) close to a year-round creek. Wasn’t sure of it at first, thinking it was some kind of lichen, but somehow lacking a thallus. Pleased to read about Stictis, and how this is essentially the same genus as what used to be called Conotrema. When living a saprotrophic lifestyle, this is the form it takes. When living a lichen lifestyle it has a similar looking form, with round, small ascocarps, black when lichenized, in a chalky white thallus.

results.notes:
Fruiting beneath Pinus contorta and Alnus rubra.
I initially keyed these to Cortinarius cf multiformis. Noah Siegel was kind enough to comment on my FB post under this image caption “talus”. The squat, abruptly bulbous, marginate stem base with slight orange staining, the red/brown rusty streaked stems(just above bulb), pale cap with deeply incurved margin, cream gills and strong fruity/musky honey odor all check out perfectly with other collections/descriptions I’ve reviewed of C. talus.
I harvested 2 specimens.
KOH to Cap: dark reddish brown.
KOH Stem: no reaction.
Spore printed half of the younger cap directly on a glass slide for spore microscopy.
Spore print: rusty reddish brown/orange.
Spores: Broadly Ellipsoid, medium sized and variably roughened(heavily in some spores analyzed and only slightly roughened in a few).
Dehydrated both specimens and bagged for herbarium collection/genetic record.

results.notes:
This is a bit odd find.
Cause I found one specimen last year, and at that time I thoght it was an tiny misplaced Psilocybe semilanceata.
And by misplaced I mean it was growing were there was logging tracks, in tall grass right next to a spruce clearcut.
But this year I went back and found more of them, like 5 of them and 3 was mature.
And now the clearcut was 2 years old.
At one spot they where more brown and at the rest of the spots they were all light grey blue.
When I picked the 3 mature ones I noticed that spruce needles was attached to one stembutt.
The mature ones was between 7 – 9 cm long and the broadest cap was 8 mm.
Also it had a very sticky and the thickest gelatinous pellicle ive ever encountered.
(More pictures will follow in later observations of this find)

I have sent spore prints and specimens away for DNA sequencing.

Edit:
I have done an experiment with trying it on wood chips & shavings which it apparently likes.
It colonizes it without any problems
So that rules out Psilocybe semilanceata.

results.notes:
Cortinarius cf albescens: This taxon is not available on MO so for now I am placing it in the Cortinarius Glaucopus Group.

Fruiting terrestrially beneath Pinus contorta.
Cap: broadly umbonate, darker at disc. Glutinous. Drying hygrophanous. Margins upturned at maturity.
KOH Cap: Mahogany Brown. See home images.
Gills: faint tan with lilac tones near margin(note specimens in image 1-2 on left).
Stem: tough, firm, long, equal and slender.
Small bulb/Marginate bulb at base.
Context: gelatinous center, white.
Context stains faintly yellow with KOH.
Odor: Green corn(very similar odor to Pseudosperma sororium).
Spore Print: rusty Brown.
Spores: moderately to heavily roughened, cylindrical to ellipsoid.
Side Laying spores: inequilateral, curved/crescent shaped.
Discussion:
The hygrophanous cap appears very similar to Kuehneromyces mutabilis in a few specimens. However, this collection bears no fruiting bodies with a single veiled stem(much less a thick persistent one, no scaly stems, nor are they fruiting caespitose in nature, nor are they on wood, nor are the gills decurrent. Also, my collection has distinctly bulbous stem bases(Marginate bulb), in addition to numerous other features lacking for K. mutabilis.
Initially keyed to Cortinarius pini based on the hygrophanous appearing cap. However, that species has gradually clavate stems(not bulbous), lacks the green corn odor and has been reported predominantly in montane locale’s here in PNW.
The unique green corn odor/bitter taste, the long, tough, slender stems with abrupt white bulb at base and faint lilac tinges remaining on gills leads me to believe this is very promising for mature/faded Cortinarius albescens. That species changes color drastically as it matures. Starting out with lilac/purple/white tones but fading to completely ocher yellow to cinnamon yellow tan tones at full maturity. The green corn odor and all other listed characters fit quite fairly well. Of course, this interesting collection could turn out to be a completely different Cortinarius in Section Phlegmacium or perhaps Glaucopodes. Labeling collection as Cortinarius glaucopus Group. Plan to have it sequenced.
Dehydrated all specimens and bagged for herbarium collection/genetic record.

results.notes:
growing were there was logging tracks, in tall grass right next to a 2 year old spruce clearcut.
At one spot they where more brown and at the rest of the spots they were all light grey blue.
Under the grass was spruce forest soil.
The mature ones was between 7 – 9 cm long and the broadest cap was 8 mm.
They had a unusual thick and sticky gelatinous pellicle.
One that was broken showed obvious bluing.
Acually went to a cowfield a kilometer away and picked another Psilocybe semilanceata for comparison.

Edit:
I have done an experiment with trying it on wood chips & shavings which it apparently likes.

Datos de Yopal: registrado en Bosque Seco Tropical (temporada de lluvia). Precipitación mínima de 15 – 25 mm en los meses de enero y diciembre, precipitación máxima 350 mm y 300 mm en los meses de mayo, junio y julio; con menos de 60 mm de lluvia en el mes más seco y precipitación anual superior a 1270 mm. Cuenta con valores mínimos de humedad relativa a inicio del año (65%), y valores más altos en junio, julio, agosto y septiembre (90-85%). Cuenta con una altura sobre el nivel del mar entre 0 y 1000 m, una pluviosidad entre 2000 y 4000 mm y temperatura promedio mayor de 24 °C, con amplitud de temperatura máxima de 8 °C, como se referencia en DANE. Los máximos valores de temperatura no sobrepasan los 36 °C y los mínimos valores no logran bajar los 19 °C que se presentan en febrero y en julio, respectivamente. Temperatura media anual mayor de 20 °C, con una estación seca y una lluviosa bien definidas (Bustamante et al., 2017; DANE, 1999; Castro y Sosa, 2017).

Se observa con frecuencia plantas representativas de la zona como Yarumo (Cecropia peltata), Jobo (Spondias mombin), Cedro (Cedrela odorata), Nauno (Albizzia guachepele), Cañafistol (Cassia moschata), Flor blanco (Tabebuia orinocensis), Uña de gato (Cynodon dactylon), entre otras.

Temperatura media anual mayor de 20 °C, con una estación seca y una lluviosa bien definidas (Bustamante et al., 2017; DANE, 1999; Castro y Sosa, 2017).

Se observa con frecuencia plantas representativas de la zona como Yarumo (Cecropia peltata), Jobo (Spondias mombin), Cedro (Cedrela odorata), Nauno (Albizzia guachepele), Cañafistol (Cassia moschata), Flor blanco (Tabebuia orinocensis), Uña de gato (Cynodon dactylon), entre otras.
results.location_name: Yopal, Casanare, Colombia

results.notes: Morphology: hemispheric or broadly-conical, grayish to pale brownish cap with furrowed edges and striated margins, delicate and quite translucent; very widely-spaced pinkish-brown gills; whitish, rather shimmery stem stains dark golden to brownish. Spore print: black. Spores: {Nov. 3rd} angularly amygdaliform (often citriniform to nearly ellipsoid), brownish [N=15] (12)12.7 – 14.1(15.1) × (6.7)7.2 – 8(8.5) µm; Me = 13.3 × 7.6 µm; Qe = 1.8. Growth pattern: solitary, infrequent. Measurements: {Oct. 29th} [n=1] cap 9.3 across by 4.5 mm high; 2.0 thick (narrowest medially) by 36.2 mm tall. {Nov. 3rd} [n=1] cap 12.3 across by 4.5 mm high; stem 1.08 thick (widens towards cap) by 27.8 mm tall. Habitat: rather well shaded pred.-deciduous woodland trailside, growing from decaying bark of twigs, emerged up from beneath a layer of moist fallen leaves.

results.notes:
Psilocybe liniformans found in east England. Posted with the kind permission of a member of the subreddit r/fimetaria who wishes to remain anonymous.

As you can see from the pictures, there is a separable gelatinous thread on the edge of the gills. The finder reported this characteristic on almost all samples examined.

Growing on horse manure.

Its location is no surprise, given its proximity to the Netherlands, where P. liniformans has been found quite extensively – especially near the coast.

Hopefully, we will get this sequenced.
results.location_name: Norwich, Norfolk, England
